sourcesContent: import React from 'react'; import { Box, Typography } from '@mui/material'; import Image from '../../assets/images/openflowmachine.png'; // Import your image const OpenFlowMachinePortfolio = () => { return ( Bringing the Open Flow Water Channel Machine to the Digital Realm Anthony Mercadante - Full Stack Software Developer {/* Blog Post Content */} The first project I undertook at my co-op placement at Mohawk College was both challenging and rewarding. We had an Open Flow Water Machine that was space-consuming and labor-intensive for student labs. My task, along with another student developer, was to recreate this machine and its functionality in virtual reality, driven by the need to save space and make lab experiments more accessible. {/* Image placeholder */} Transitioning to a VR setup enabled students to conduct their experiments using VR headsets provided by the college. This not only made the labs more accessible but also allowed the college to repurpose the space previously occupied by the physical machine. The transition to VR was a game-changer, offering a blend of practicality and innovation. {/* YouTube Video Embed */} The most daunting task in this project was developing the water simulation. Creating realistic water in a virtual environment required immersing myself in fluid dynamics. The accuracy of the lab experiments heavily depended on the water's behavior, making this aspect of the project crucial. {/* Additional sections for Simulation Approach, Computational Challenges, etc. */} In developing the water simulation, I had to decide between Lagrangian, Eulerian, or hybrid methods. This choice was critical as it influenced how we would represent and simulate the fluid in our VR environment. For large-scale effects, I used grid-based simulations (Eulerian Methods), storing fluid properties in grid cells. To approximate fluid molecules, I simulated numerous particles (Lagrangian Methods), employing techniques like position-based dynamics. Combining both approaches (Hybrid Methods), I managed grid and particle data to create a more comprehensive fluid simulation. Simulating fluids in VR posed several challenges, from achieving high-resolution details to managing computational loads and addressing advection difficulties. A significant part of the project involved integrating the fluid simulation with Unity, considering the engine's capabilities and limitations to create a seamless VR experience. This project was not just about applying existing knowledge but also about learning on the go. I had to teach myself the intricacies of fluid dynamics to ensure the simulation's accuracy. The water had to act precisely as it would in real life for the students to complete their labs effectively. The project was a resounding success. We managed to create a virtual Open Flow Water Machine that not only saved space but also enhanced the learning experience for students. It was a testament to the power of VR in education and the potential of Unity as a tool for creating complex simulations. This project at Mohawk College was more than just a co-op placement task; it was a journey that honed my skills in simulation, VR, and programming. It underscored the importance of practical application in learning and the endless possibilities that technology offers in transforming education. ); }; export default OpenFlowMachinePortfolio;
